title: Bring back Tribunal or make the punishment system fair, instead of demonising.

embed.description: Riot Games is biased, hypocritical and delusional Some articles & blog post for those interested about a topic I didn't get to talk about in this 3 parts video, but it's an example to underline my opinion about Riot's hypocrisy & bias when it comes to their general mindset inside

body:
Very close to home for many players this series is.

Change your punishment system to actually work.

Riot needs educate their players better so they understand how the system actually works and improve the transparency behind it.

> [{quoted}](name=DespicableCee,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=f7iLOT8a,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-01-08T00:16:17.895+0000)

I don't know anyone--including Riot--who doesn't think trolling needs better detection, or that chat is easier spot offenses.

A big part of the problem is players who are so sure they get trolls every game, they can't tell the difference between low skill or bad matchups from actual trolling.  They report players for off-meta or a different playstyle/build than expected.  It introduces a lot of false flags into the system that Riot has to filter out to avoid banning innocent players.

> [{quoted}](name=DespicableCee,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=f7iLOT8a,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-01-08T00:16:17.895+0000)
>
> I understand where your perspective is , but thats him being political and dodging the question.  At the moment I can strongly argue that right NOW that people are being more punished from flaming rather than trolls/intentional feeding.

We don't have quantum computers yet. Does that mean no one has working on it?

Riot knows and states that, yes, it is harder to detect inting than flaming. Because you have to detect intent. It takes longer, however, punishment is harsher.

This clearly proves how much you don't know about Tribunal nor do you even have a hint of understanding what the IFS is how far superior it is compared to Tribunal. Riot needs to really show how useless Tribunal is and what IFS is all about.

Ever played counter strike go? their player based overwatch system is actually half decent, I don't think that's an unfeasible system to turn tribunal into, hell offer a small amount of riot points to those who successfully review cases. This is a Multi-Billion Dollar company whose (if you're honest and don't fanboy/girl) current biggest word of mouth, is that it's an extremely Toxic game.

Many of the cases took months to complete because of the backlog it generated, and it mostly came to the same result as the current system.

How would it be less demonizing for the verdicts to be passed by the community weeks or even months after the bad behavior? That sounds **more** demonizing if you're given a punishment only based on behavior you showed several months ago.

I think you should present why you think a punishment you received is unfair, not some video of a guy reviewing another guy's video.

I see a lot of chat logs here, and rarely do I see ones that didn't deserve some level of punishment.

Another guy: Shaclone. And he's pretty well aware of what triggers punishments.

We both know there's no point in actually doing that, and I haven't received a punishment in many months, my last one was for flaming a guy who literally ran it down 10 times more after I said, and I quote "Please jinx stop playing so overly aggressive against a lane that already has 4 kills on you" and "Jinx, please stop doing that" then received in response, flaming I could barely understand, except for the expleetives in the messages, so I defend myself because at this point I'd lost my promos for the 3rd time to this, and was UNDERSTANDABLY annoyed. The current system does not have context, in disputes in courts, wether civil or crown *state/federal in the us* context and fact is very important. It's not a reaction video more than it is a discussion about the state of league.

I've already tried making this case. Unfortunately riot doesn't actually care about context, as the support agents are only there to confirm whether or not the toxicity bot properly flagged something toxic. Riot then suggest you take the context to the community, (as in, this forum) where the community and moderators will then /disregard/ literally all of the context, look at the chat logs, and say, "Yep, that chat log was toxic."

Which is stupid. 

Picture this, you're playing a game of league with all chat disabled in a 1v1 match. You say in team chat, "Kys."

Your chatlog for that game (as it would be shown from your reform card) would simply be,
<Player> : Kys

Even though that chat log is from a game where you were literally talking to yourself and no-one else could see it, that's all that would be on the chat log.

Now naturally you'd never get reported for that as the other player didn't see anything to report, but had they arbitrarily reported you in that situation,  BlitzcrankBot would've spotted that "kys" post game in the chat log, and you'd receive a harsh penalty (because inciting self harm is a huge no-no to riot)

So, why was that strange example important? Perspective. 

Imagine now you're in a ranked game at literally any level of ranked play, and after receiving 20 minutes of uncontested flame from your team, you simply say, "Kys"

Once again, your post game chat log as seen from your player reform card would look like the following:
<Player>: Kys

Interestingly enough, BOTH of these cases would be treated with equally harsh punishment, because simply put: Riot doesn't care about context, and neither does the community. It's unfortunate, really.
What does this have to do with player behavior?
This is why '/mute all' is a beautiful, beautiful thing.

The reform card shows that player what they said.
When a player is reported the entire chat log including all is viewed iirc.
Yeah, the punishment system could definitely do with some improvement. Very few players who deserve a punishment actually get one.
